Whether you're twentysomething and go to dance clubs or of her generation and more likely to hit the gym, the whole CD makes you want to move your body...and keep going! B000092Q7O|5.0|Roman Polanski's \\"The Pianist\\" tracks the incredible struggle for survival of Wladyslaw Szpilman, a Polish Jewish pianist in 1930s Warsaw. As the film opens, Wladyslaw is recording on Polish radio, but a bombing raid forces him out of the studio and into the panicked streets. We soon meet his family: a headstrong brother, gentle sisters, and aged parents who are aghast at the more and more extreme measures taken to dehumanize Polish Jews: wearing armbands, not allowed to walk on sidewalks, not allowed to sit on benches in public parks or eat in Gentile establishments, and finally, the move to the Ghetto. Wladyslaw's tight-knit family struggles to stay together as conditions become more and more dire.<br /><br />The film traces the disintegration of order in Warsaw from 1939 to 1945. Wladyslaw's life goes to new lows as the Ghetto is evacuated to the work (death) camps, and he must go into hiding, his situation becoming more and more dire as he is forced to flee from place to place and scrabble for food. He is taken advantage of, nearly dies from jaundice, and is nearly killed several times, but throughout the music in his head, heart and fingertips still burns brightly. Towards the end of the war, a single act of kindness by a Nazi commander proves that there is still decency in humanity, and finally Wladyslaw is once more able to give the world his musical gift over Polish radio.<br /><br />This film, while perhaps not on the same level as Schindler's list (there is very little dialogue for much of the film, and as other reviewers have mentioned, it becomes an almost Cast Away tale of solitary survival at its rawest), highlights the indignities perpetrated against European Jews. Dead bodies litter the streets, and the Nazis indiscriminately kill or humiliate whoever they so desire. Human dignity has no worth. The film's violence serves to underscore how much like animals humans can become, filled with primitive blood lust, or like the Jews in the Ghetto, forced to survive on an animal level: an old man attacks an old woman to steal her food, and as the mush splashes on the filthy pavement, he hungrily stuffs it into his mouth off the ground. This is powerful filmmaking, based in part on some of Polanski's own remembrances. (Rated R for graphic violence).to survive on an animal level: an old man attacks an old woman to steal her food, and as the mush splashes on the filthy pavement, he hungrily stuffs it into his mouth off the ground. This is powerful filmmaking, based in part on some of Polanski's own remembrances. (Rated R for graphic violence). <br /> <br /> <br />

B0000CEB4V|5.0|Even though this has a five-star rating with more than 280 reviews in, I think it's worth restating what a gem this DVD really is.   <br /> <br />The quality of the performances is top-notch, from the brilliant Indian pieces music and the Python segment right through to the efforts of Clapton, McCartney, Petty et al.  The artists were chosen perfectly with all having had real connections to George (there were none of the usual artists who pile on at tribute time).  Clapton gets a free pass through the Pearly Gates for the way he put together the musical components of the show. <br /> <br />The real reason I want to comment on this, though, is the quality of the production.  It's a visual delight.  <br /> <br />In an age where rapid-fire editing is absolutely ruining a lot of (most?) concert DVDs, this film gets it right.  The camera work is by no means static, but there's no ADD-induced jumping around either.  Shots are held long enough and there are plenty of perspective shots of the ensemble.  The cameras acknowledge the audience but don't keep coming back to it.  Which means the viewer can savour the concert - musically AND visually - without being distracted by superficial editing nonsense. <br /> <br />In short, it's perfect.  Or it would have been had George made the gig! <br /> <br />
B0000019PA|5.0|The theme of the album, as you may know, is the life of Anne Frank. Or more specifically the time she was hidden in an attic room in Amsterdam and the fate that later befell her.  <br /> <br />This is like watching a play or a concert put on by the occupants of those cramped rooms. The costumes are homemade out of what they can find. The performances are amateur but endearing. The audience applaud even the mistakes. The instruments sometimes sound cracked and broken as they \\"... dance round the room to accordion keys\\". But as a lump may have been brought to the throat of the proud parents, so will you find this at times. <br /> <br />The title track is quite wonderful, and so are the two parts of Two Headed Boy.  <br /> <br />The cover art comes from an earlier Edwardian period but wouldn't this be the same for some of the family's cherished possessions? Perhaps an old toy, or a sewing box. <br /> <br />Its an album that's been painstakingly put together, and Magnum has produced one of the very few pieces in the \\"Popular Music\\" cannon that can also be judged as a work of Art. His genuine feeling for the subject permeates the whole, and the lyrics, although at times obscure, are worth your efforts, as they span the whole claustrophobic and sometimes sexually charged atmosphere - \\"Your father made fetuses with flesh licking ladies. While you and your mother were asleep in the trailer park\\", together with the soaring escapism of Anne's diary \\"Anna's ghost all around. Hear her voice as it's rolling and ringing through me soft and sweet. How the notes all bend and reach above the trees\\" , and graphically illustrate the barbarity of her fate - \\"And they'll be placing fingers through the notches in your spine\\"  <br /> <br /> <br />At just under 40 minutes the album flies by. <br /> <br />You should buy this and cherish it.

B000BB1MI2|4.0|Danny Elfman's score begins. I hate Danny Elfman, but of course he would be used, he's in every one of Burton's endeavors. A CGI factory makes CGI chocolate in what seems like a mockery of the same imagery used to make cookies in the beginning of Edward Scissorhands... the narrator starts; in Burton's typical fairy-tale style comes images of fairy-tale times with fairy-tale dilapidated old houses, and I'm really beginning to not like it until...<br /><br />...it all sucks you in. You watch Charlie's family as they anticipate the finders of the Golden Tickets, and their quite acute comments on the nature of the winners. You watch as Charlie simultaneously tries to hide his hope and maintain it at the same time, along with his family's fluctuating eagerness to get a Golden Ticket. And as Charlie finds a ten dollar bill on the ground, you suddenly realize, \\"Geez, this movie's a lot like the book... well, of course it was one dollar and not ten dollars, but who's really counting?\\" And a lot like the book it stays, with a few minor deviations which frankly are brilliant. Wonka's flashbacks into his childhood are perfect addendums to Depp's quirky new creation of the beloved character that most could not separate from Wilder, and in the end Wilder's character is still maintained because he is not blaspheme'd. Johnny Depp and Tim Burton make a new Willy Wonka that is standalone enough that all thought of Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory becomes mere nitpicking by people annoyed by change.<br /><br />In fact, considering the book, Willy Wonka movie, and Charlie movie, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is truly brilliant. It holds true to the book while still maintaining cinematic appeal by becoming it's own thing. It is not a remake of Willy Wonka, and thank God (or just Burton, as it was his choice anyways, right?) for that, because even though I like the older version, remakes are just incredibly tedious.<br /><br />Special appeal to Burton fans would be the almost demented acting of Johnny Depp... the strange grins when kids get in trouble, the timid voice when he becomes unsure of himself, the reclusive germophobe he makes of a once maudlin and glurgy character. In fact, all the characters are perfectly translated to the screen, even if they do look like porcelain dolls from time to time (I hypothesize this comes from the drawings found in many of Rhoad Dahl's books).<br /><br />Another great aspect of this movie is it's adherence to the musical bits in the book without really being a musical itself. Other than one other song, the Oompa Loompas sing everything, and though their music isn't really that good (I'd like to have it on a CD for laughs, but I don't really care for it otherwise), at least the situations are pretty funny, especially since all of the Oompa Loompas have the same face... and aren't like Munchkins.<br /><br />Another good thing to focus on is the insane amount of allusions.  Did I say \\"mockery of Edward Scissorhands\\"?  It's no mockery, the beginning channels that work for a reason.  Kubrick, Hitchcock, and Burton's own films are easy catches, but can you catch all of the homages in this film?<br /><br />As the movie progresses, it deviates more and more from the book, which is fine because it feels at that point like the trust has been salvaged. If people are still worrying about details so far into this movie, then I don't really see how they enjoy very many movies at all. About the time we reach the television room scene, it begins to feel a little tedious but right then wraps up everything pretty nicely (not to say there isn't more good stuff to come, but I'm not going to give away ALL the details). Eventually the credits roll and I'm suddenly realizing, \\"Wow, that was two hours... felt like two minutes.\\" A sure sign of a pretty good movie if there is one.<br /><br />--PolarisDiBmost demented acting of Johnny Depp... the strange grins when kids get in trouble, the timid voice when he becomes unsure of himself, the reclusive germophobe he makes of a once maudlin and glurgy character. 0440237688|5.0|I was always encouraged to read this in middle school, but I never got around to it.  Now I'm a twenty-something, and we selected this for a book club discussion, and I was completely blown away!  I highly recommend this as a book club selection because it is short enough that everyone can finish it on time, but it packs a serious punch and there are dozens of published discussion questions and ways to explore the book.<br /><br />There's no need for me to recount the plot in this review, and doing so wouldn't explain why this book is so essential.  It has timeless themes, one that will be studied by students for years to come, I am sure.  This is an outstanding book for any teacher wanting to discuss diversity, and how our individualism makes our world so wonderful.  My one word of caution is that the book is deceptively simple to read.  I've heard of 5th and 6th grade teachers teaching the book, and while it is technically readable at that grade level, some of the themes about reproduction, adolesence, and the like are more appropriate for students who are just a few grades more advanced.  Other reviewers have mentioned the age-appropriateness of this book, too.  I recommend it to middle schoolers, no younger, despite the fact that it is technically readable at a younger age.  Middle school students will be able to identify with the changes Jonas is going through as he matures.

0385510454|3.0|This book meanders like nothing else.  There was some sharp political and legal action, and then Grisham got completely lost in character development.  There were paper-thin plot strands running around everywhere that didn't get tied up by the end of the novel.<br /><br />So many reviewers have said it, but I need to add my voice--this book is a love affair with Italy.  There is no reason for our main character to be hiding in this foreign country, not knowing the language, other than as a convenient plot device for Grisham to throw out Italian history and culture.  Is this a travel guide or a legal thriller? (It is the former, for most of the novel.)<br /><br />The absolute worst is Grisham's closing notes, in which he explains that he knows little of electronic gadgets and espionage.  Is this supposed to be some lame apology for not doing his research correctly before writing a book about modern internet-based espionage?  Email is a mystery in this book--it can be instantly 100% secure when it is convenient to the author, completely unbreakable, or, if he needs it as a plot device, Grisham can devote pages to complicated adventures to thwart email spies.  Please, do your homework and write a consistent novel!

0895260131|5.0|To the reviewer below who speaks of the \\"sad state of things\\": I'd say people writing reviews of books they obviously haven't read is pretty sad.  Does this guy actually think Spencer doesn't deal with the absurd \\"jihad refers merely to internal struggle\\" argument?  Or that he doesn't address the supposed \\"no compulsion in religion\\" argument? <br /> <br />Spencer's book is not the product of ignorance.  Calling Islam the \\"religion of peace\\" is the product of ignorance. <br /> <br />Spencer clearly notes that most Muslims are neither evil nor inclined toward terrorism.  What he does say is that everything a jihadist needs from an ideological point of view is just waiting there in Islamic teaching for him to exploit. <br /> <br />And don't give me the argument that Christians have had their faults too, since that proves you haven't read the book.  Spencer answers this argument.  If you disagree with his perspective, fine, but if you're going to prove to me that you read the book you at least have to acknowledge that it exists. <br /> <br />The fact is, whenever a suicide bombing occurs these days, no one says, \\"There go the Methodists again!\\"  Why is that, exactly?  And what exactly is wrong with at least posing the question? <br /> <br />As for the \\"no compulsion in religion,\\" Spencer shows that major Islamic scholars consider those peaceful verses to be \\"cancelled\\" today.  Islamic apologists like the one-star reviewers here then cite the peaceful verses, without mentioning that they've been \\"cancelled,\\" and then have the nerve to accuse SPENCER of taking Islamic verses out of context! <br /> <br />Read this book for yourself and see which side of this debate is really playing fast and loose with the facts. <br /> <br />(Oh, and by the way, although most Muslims are indeed not terrorists, imagine this: suppose 9/11 had been perpetrated by Mother Teresa's nuns.  We'd never hear the end of all the Catholic apologies.  Catholics would be heading up all the relief efforts, would be coordinating anti-terrorist seminars, going after Catholics who teach terrorism, etc.  The response would be swift and systematic.  In the Muslim world, on the other hand, we get the occasional muted protest -- with the notable recent exception of the Lebanese -- that is always hedged by qualifying phrases and excuse-making.  Why are we permitted to draw no conclusion from this?)

B000AADYYO|5.0|Many an Opeth fan likely has had mixed feelings about the directions the band has taken in the time and events leading up to this album.  After their 2003 album _Damnation_, many had thought that Opeth had \\"gone soft\\" (a great misunderstanding, as the band had originally planned on releasing _Damnation_ along with its predecessor, the ultra-heavy _Deliverance_, as a two-disc album of two wholly contrasting songs).  What's more, they ended up leaving their longtime record label Koch to join the far more mainstream label Roadrunner.  And if that wasn't enough, Opeth hired a fifth full-time member - a keyboardist!  What all these things could amount to, nobody was sure.  Ultimately, however, these changes were for the best; on August 30th this year, Opeth released what may well be their best and most varied work to date. <br /> <br />On _Ghost Reveries_, Opeth's musical style may at first appear to be the same as they've always composed: ultra-heavy riffs and death metal vocals, as well as mellow, acoustic/clean electric guitar and tender vocals, all within the same song.  However, there are several differences on this album, some subtle, and others more obvious.  For one thing, there are actually more clean vocals on this album than any of their previous (heavy) records - again, this is not to say that Opeth have \\"gone soft.\\" <br /> <br />Opeth had recently been incorporating keyboard sounds and styles into their music more and more (a big influence of the producer of their past three albums, Porcupine Tree leader Steve Wilson); the arrival of Per Wiberg into Opeth's lineup made for a perfect opportunity to further explore this new style.  A former touring member for Opeth as well as studio/touring member of Spiritual Beggars and Arch Enemy, Mr. Wiberg is no stranger to keyboard-metal fusion.  A few highlights include the beautiful harmonies in the choruses of \\"Isolation Years,\\" the atmospheric background harmonies and excellent piano melodies in \\"Atonement,\\" and thebrilliant, swirling sounds and textures in the outro to \\"Beneath the Mire.\\" <br /> <br />Even with the various new directions explored, _Ghost Reveries_ is still distinctly recognizable being Opeth.  The melodic metal stylings, the emotional vocals, the acoustic breaks - it's all here.  Songs such as \\"The Baying of the Hounds,\\" \\"Beneath the Mire,\\" and \\"Ghost of Perdition\\" could have (more or less) been on _Blackwater Park_ or _Deliverance_; there are a couple of ballads (the aforementioned \\"Atonement\\" and \\"Isolation Years\\"), and there's even a short instrumental (immediately following \\"Atonement\\" on the same track) comprised of clean electric guitar strumming and keyboard harmonies. <br /> <br />The rest of the band is in great shape.  Mikael's switching up his death metal voice a bit more (using the higher, raspier tones of such early albums as _Orchid_ and _Morningrise_ as much as the deepest growls of _Blackwater Park_ and _Deliverance_), and his singing voice has not been more crisp.  The guitar styles from Peter Lindgren and Mikael are naturally in top form (distorted and clean electric, and of course acoustic) as they continue to weave beautiful harmonies with ultra-heavy riffs with brilliant ease.  Martin Mendez has usually followed the traditional path as a metal bassist (i.e. generally being lost in the heaviness), but on _Ghost Reveries_, his bass lines are actually quite audible most of the time for a change (likely due to the band's self-production).  And let's not forget Martin Lopez behind the rhythm section, skillfully adding the right bone structure to each song with his versatile and highly distinct playing styles, while adding some new touches (most notably the conga beats switching up with a more jazz-oriented percussion on \\"Atonement\\"). <br /> <br />The entire album is worth a listen, and as a whole, it is simply a masterpiece.  However, there is one song which is a particular standout which deserves a large amount of attention on its own, and that is the dark epic \\"The Grand Conjuration.\\"  The song is largely driven by the same harmony, played alternately in faster and slower tempos (over which Mikael's growl sounds more monstrous than ever).  It's during the verses where the true power of this song lurks; the main harmony is played in a slow, absolutely menacing series of riffs, with Mikael's singing voice low and distinctly cold as he recites a chant to a dark deity.  The song starts off dark, but it gets even darker, reaching into the blackest voids of infinity with a harrowing display of evocative songwriting, touching on the twisted center of evil in such a simple series of keyboard and guitar notes.  This might not make a lot of sense in any kind of description; rather, it takes only a listen to make one understand the quiet, brooding menace of this song. <br /> <br />There's not much more that can really be said about this album, simply because it leaves the listener speechless with awe.  With such brave exploration and originality on this album, more so than ever before, Opeth have created what is likely THE progressive metal album of 2005.  Going beyond anyone's expectations and even beyond any of their own previous excursions into progressive music, _Ghost Reveries_ is, without a doubt, Opeth's finest and best album to date, and simply put, a masterpiece.
B00006RINF|4.0|If you havn't heard of this album yet, you're out of the loop and you need to buy it (just joking). B000001FTQ|4.0|Wide Awake in America is an EP released after U2's career-defining appearance at 1985's Live Aid.  It consists of live performances of \\"Bad\\" (NOT the version from Live Aid) and \\"A Sort of Homecoming,\\" both from 1984's The Unforgettable Fire, as well as two outtakes from that album, \\"Love Comes Tumbling\\" and \\"The Three Sunrises.\\"<br /><br />\\"Bad\\" was recorded in November of 1984 in Birmingham, England (not in the U.S. as the EP's title suggests), well before Live Aid.  This version of the song is absolutely amazing- it's infused with all the passion of the studio version as well as the energy from the audience.  \\"A Sort of Homecoming\\" was recorded at London's Wembley Arena several days later as a soundcheck- the audience noise was edited in later.  While knowing that somewhat dampens my enjoyment of the track, I still must say that it's performed with great energy and enthusiasm that were less present on the studio version.<br /><br />The two studio tracks are quite good, and I agree with the other reviewers that say that they belong on The Unforgettable Fire in place of some of the questionable material from that album (\\"Elvis Presley & America\\" in particular).  \\"Love Comes Tumbling\\" is a slower, brooding piece not unlike \\"Bad\\" or the title track from The Unforgettable Fire.  \\"The Three Sunrises\\" is more joyous and uptempo, and has a sing-along feel to it.  These are two of the best U2 B-sides.<br /><br />Wide Awake in America is a fantastic EP and something that I'd recommend to anyone interested in U2.  However, there's the matter of this being an EP that's sold at an LP's price.  Myself, I downloaded the whole album from iTunes for $4.  That's probably the best way to go with this.
0553801503|4.0|Martin's new Feast is pretty slim pickings, and its no surprise. For those of us who have been following the series it should be obvious that this book would be the weakest in the series. George Martin originally tried to skip over this period in his story, but found he couldn't make it work. He came back to this part to fill it in, but ended up writing so much that his publisher wouldn't publish it as one volume. To keep the story coherent he decided to cut out half the characters instead of half the story. This book is in essence half of a new exposition for the third act. <br /> <br />So its no surprise then that Feast does not deliver like the other books. The conflicts that drove the first three have ground to a halt, and the characters who are doing exciting things are cut out of this installment. For now the story, like the kingdom of Westeros, has had all the fight beaten out of it. <br /> <br />On the other hand, this is George Martin, and his writing style and uniquely realistic fantasy are back. Arya and Sam break out of the monotony with exciting and revealing chapters (easily the best in the book), and Jaime continues his transformative character arc. The book suffers from its place in the series structure and the publishers' pocketbooks, but it is still recognizable as a product of one of fanstasy's modern masters.

0679731369|4.0|This very charming and lively study of the life and work of Gustave Flaubert poses an interesting question: would you rather read a book about a subject matter that completely mirrors reality or a book that takes some license with the truth for the sake of art?  The narrator of _Flaubert's Parrot_, Dr. Braithwaite, a Flaubert afficianado, delves into the master's literature and into his personal background, and comes up with various sets of facts depending upon the point of view of the source.  Mr. Barnes quotes Louise Colet, a poet and Flaubert's mistress, Flaubert's friends, as well as citing from Flaubert's masterpiece, _Madame Bovary_.  Mr. Barnes also presents the reader with two alternate chronologies of Flaubert's life, one idyllic and the other providing quite the opposite impression.    What I found particularly delightful about this book was the narrator's discussion of the parrot in Flaubert's novella, _A Simple Heart_.  Braithwaite compares the colors of the alleged real stuffed parrot, supposedly acting as Flaubert's muse while  writing _A Simple Heart_, with the parrot's description in the novella.  There is even some doubt that the bird-muse that Braithwaite temporarily has in his possession was in actuality Flaubert's.  Braithwaite also quotes from a Flaubert critic who chastizes Flaubert for his consistent inaccuracy in stating the color of Emma Bovary's eyes, rather than concerning herself with the novel's artistic merits.    _Flaubert's Parrot_ also concerns itself with Braithwaite's sad personal life, which may help explain some of his interest in Flaubert's romantic entanglements.  This helps to lend this book a multi-faceted flavor. That, together with its rich detail and its unique take on art and its critics, makes _Flaubert's Parrot_ an unusually holding work.

B00004TH7Z|5.0|I have Powerslave, Number of the Beast, and Piece of Mind. I just recently got Brave New World. Maybe I'm crazy, but Brave New World is my favorite so far. It has a bit of everything, Number of the Beast style rockers and then it has progressive songs such as songs off of Somewhere In Time and 7th Son. The first half of the disc has \\"shorter\\" rockers(if you consider 6 minutes short). The second half has the big epics. These are all great. The instrumental sections of these songs are hair raising as well. I'm going to give a song by song review of the album <br /> <br />Song-By-Song Review: <br /> <br />1. The Wicker Man (10/10)- I hear this is the big hit off the CD. I can see why, the chorus is amazingly catchy. There is an extremely addictive little melody, and the double bass drums sound good during the chorus. Another great Maiden opener that stands tall with the other Maiden openers. It also has lots of clean guitar parts. It builds into another great chorus. Brucey shines here. I give it 8 because it can get slightly tedious. Nice harmonies, and the chorus is so huge sounding. The chorus is repeated many, many times but it is so good you won't notice or care. <br /> <br />6. Dream of Mirrors (7/10)- Maybe I am impatient, but this song takes a little too long to get to its climax. I never skip it, but I have to focus to keep from zoning out. At 9 minutes, this is one of the longer songs. <br /> <br />7. The Fallen Angel (10/10)- This one is like the Wicker Man, its one of the shortest songs at 4 minutes and also one of the catchiest and best. The solo's and chorus are great.  <br /> <br />8. Nomad (11/10)- This song is another of the epics. Its nine minutes(or eight?) of epic music with an Arabian feeling to it. Bruce's vocals are godly here. I love the chorus(is there one weak chorus on this whole album?). The song in my opinion should have been placed before Nomad, that way have Nomad and The Thin Line would be consecutive to each other. <br /> <br />10. The Thin Line Between Love and Hate (11/10)- I could get sacrficed for this, but I like this even more than Hallowed Be Thy Name...yes it's that good. It's 9 minutes long and still too short. Contains great verses, choruses, harmonies, and the ending part where Bruce sings, \\"The Thin Line between Love and Hate\\" with the clean guitars is amazing. This song has Bruce's best vocals. <br /> <br />Overall: <br />This is my favorite of the 4 Maiden CD's I have because I find no weak tracks at all. As great as those earlier ones are, I found some weak spots or tracks I would skip. Piece had Quest For Fire, and Number has Gangland. I love this progressive sound that Iron Maiden uses. I definitely want to get 7th son and Somewhere In Time as they are probably even better albums. If you want emotional, epic, and skilled music buy this. I promise you will enjoy this.

This book needed some heavy editing, and if it had been edited, maybe yet another book would not have been necessary. I was very taken with Martin's writing style in the first three books, and I found it refreshingly different, but when it's strung out, it can be excruciatingly boring. I will not pre-order the next book, but will wait for good reviews before buying. Caveat emptor!

B000BGH22W|4.0|There is always a certain amount of anticipation and dread when a new composer takes over for a well known composer in a major film series.  Just look at the various responses here along with this review.  Sometimes the dread is well placed; note what horrible things followed when Bill Conti and Marvin Hamlisch took over for John Barry in the James Bond series.  Fear not with Patrick Doyle's score for the fourth Harry Potter entry, \\"Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire.\\"  From the first notes of \\"The Story Continues\\" Doyle's music dispells any worries, and pulls you into the  magical world of Hogwarts.  Interweaving obligatory main themes by the great John Williams, and developing his own themes and motifs, Doyle has put together music that goes beyond just \\"serviceable.\\"  Indeed, in places it's \\"bloody  brilliant.\\"  Menacing, majestic, mysterious, heroic, even romantic and amusing, Patrick Doyle hits all the right notes; even \\"Neville's Waltz\\" and \\"Potter's Waltz\\" come off well.  Certainly, Williams is missed, but this is a very capable, and enjoyable score that should not be underestimated. The soundtrack recording is nicely produced and packaged by Warners Sunset/Warner Brtothers, but some may be put off by the songs tacked on as the final three cuts (other vocals such as those in \\"Underwater Secrets,\\" on the other hand, work very well).  Welcome to Hogwarts Mr. Doyle!  <br />

0689859414|5.0|Do you hear something knocking on the walls of your house at night? Do you keep losing bobby pins, pencils, or spools of thread? Have you woken up to find that all the laces of your shoes are tied together and that your dog has a large bald spot on its head? If you answered \\"yes\\" to any or all of these questions, then there can be no doubt that you have a member of the faerie world living in your home. Is it a boggart, a brownie, or a knocker? What do these mysterious creatures look like?    Within the pages of this remarkable guide you will find the answers to these and many other questions. Without a doubt this is one of the most comprehensive and fascinating books of its kind. Co-authors Holly Black and Tony DiTerlizzi have taken pages from Arthur Spiderwick's famous Guide and used them to create a book that is beautiful to look at and full of valuable and useful information. Where else will you learn how to stay on the right side of a brownie, and how else will you know that the gargoyles you see on buildings may in fact be alive?    Packed with luscious color illustrations and numerous pencil sketches, this book is a must for fans of The Spiderwick Chronicles. Readers of all ages will get lost in the pages (some of which fold out to reveal beautiful illustrations) and in no time will be convinced that they indeed are looking at the life's work of Arthur Spiderwick, which thankfully has been reproduced here by the talented duo of Holly Black and Tony DiTerlizzi.       --- Reviewed by Marya Jansen-Gruber, editor of Through The Looking Glass Children's Book Review ([...])  [...]

1416905014|5.0|For ages, people have been enchanted by the story of Cinderella. Told again and again throughout literary history by writers like Charles Perrault, Hans Christian Andersen, the Brothers Grimm and Walt Disney, this classic tale continually finds its way into the hearts and imaginations of children of all ages. In his latest work, illustrator and paper engineer extraordinaire Matthew Reinhart joins the ranks of these illustrious storytellers by breathing new life and a new kind of magic into a centuries-old story with CINDERELLA: A POP-UP FAIRY TALE. <br /> <br />Through Reinhart's painstakingly elaborate pop-up settings constructed on six spreads of the tale's most famous scenes, a whimsical and larger-than-life world unfolds, inviting readers into the fantasy realm of three-dimensional glass slippers and fairy godmothers. Elegant ballroom dancers twirl across their laps and nobles' steeds jump from the pages to create a truly mesmerizing and breathtaking experience. As if these weren't wondrous enough, several mini pop-ups open to reveal even more intricately detailed cardboard cutouts that move along with the pages, adding to the book's charm and appeal. <br /> <br />In this beloved fairy tale where good always overcomes evil and true love prevails, Reinhart offers a rich and stunning vision that will captivate and enthrall a whole new generation of readers for years to come. <br /> <br />   --- Reviewed by Marisa Emralino

B000002I4W|5.0|1959 was probably the biggest year for jazz in history. Out of that year we were introduced to instant classics such as \\"Kind of Blue\\", \\"Giant Steps\\", \\"Time Out\\", \\"Mingus Ah Um\\" and of course, Ornette Colemans \\"Shape of Jazz to Come.\\" It is not surprising Coleman's release was originally criticized by many as the red-headed step child of jazz music. Many were outraged by Coleman's tunes that lacked an explicit form or set of chord changes. However, much of what we listen to now in the contemporary world of jazz has been shaped by this important artistic album.<br /><br />If one listens to many of the groups that are on the contemporary scene these days such as the Dave Holland Quintet, it is very hard to discern any type of particular form or distinct chord changes that the players are improvising over. The reason you can't tell very easily is because well, there isn't one. We have Ornette Coleman to thank for this innovative concept that has created an entirely different world of jazz for us to enjoy. Many of the contemporary groups today have extracted much from the avant garde concepts that Coleman initiated on this record.<br /><br />One might be curious, how in the world can players improvise when there is no explicit form or chordal structure? The answer lies in one word: chemistry. The interplay between Charlie Haden (bass) and Billy Higgins (drums) with the soloists (Coleman on sax and Don Cherry on coronet) is amazing. The players are always conscious of what the others are doing at any given second. Because the chemistry between the players is so well-developed, the music has bite, edge and a sort of abrasiveness that rarely if ever sounds racous, out of tune or unmusical. Granted it is abstract and unconventional, but it stays away from being so vaporous that it cannot be comprehended by the untrained ear (an issue that some contemporary musicians err on too much).<br /><br />The only warning that I have about this album is that it is not intended to be background music of any kind. You can turn on Kind of Blue or Time Out and occupy yourself with something else and be just fine. This is not the case with \\"Shape of Jazz to Come.\\" Coleman's disc requires a much more attentive and engaged ear to really appreciate it. Many of the people who refer to this album as incoherent abstract garbage probably are not listening to the album the way it was meant to be listened to. Listen closely and you too, may truely appreciate the shape that jazz has taken.o be background music of any kind. You can turn on Kind of Blue or Time Out and occupy yourself with something else and be just fine. This is not the case with \\"Shape of Jazz to Come.\\" Coleman's disc requires a much more attentive and engaged ear to really appreciate it. Many of the people who refer to this album as incoherent abstract garbage probably are not listening to the album the way it was meant to be listened to. Listen closely and you too, may truely appreciate the shape that jazz has taken.
B000005JA8|5.0|This album is absolutely amazing. I am completely unschooled in music theory, and although I listen to a good deal of the composers to whom Beefheart is compared, I don't pretend to understand what makes them great. <br /> <br />With that said, it strikes me as obvious and undeniable that Trout Mask Replica is a work of art. Everything I find bland and predictable in contemporary and \\"classic\\" rock and roll is simply absent in Beefheart's music. His songs lack repetitive, cyclical choruses and verses. His vocal range is astonishing. Rather than paying a guy to tap out the same 4:4 drum beat for 3 and a half minutes, his (often spastic) rhythms are consistently kept with creative, engaging drum fills.  All the instruments meander in directions that are both complementary and completely at odds with each other.  <br /> <br />More importantly, and on this I stand in direct opposition to any negative reviews that this album has received, most of the songs sound good. I really love the song Ella Guru. Pachuco Cadaver is genuinely fun to listen to. In Hobo Chang Ba, after all the instruments go around for a while and finally come back together in the end, the vocals add an entirely new dimension to the melody, and it's just brutal as hell.  <br /> <br />In summation, I really didn't notice how boring most of the music I listened to was until after hearing this record. Go buy this at a record store and avoid fueling the fire of amazonian corporate greed.
B000B8IA2G|4.0|As far as I am concerned, this boxed set is at the higher-end of mediocre spectrum.    In the show, The Ancients, the builders of the stargates and ancestor of modern humans left in a city-ship called Atlantis to the Pegasus galaxy and never returned.  10 million years later, an international team of scientists and military go on a one-way trip to Pegasus and discover the city underpowered, underwater, unihabited and hidden from Pegasus' version of thte Goa'uld: The Wraith.    PROS: The interior design and cover art is pretty good (in contrast to the box cover).  There are 4 episodes per disc, and each one is in 1.78:1 aspect ratio; the episodes themselves are 1.5-1.6GB in size, the same size as the disappointing MACGYVER boxed set episodes, but definitely better.  The sound, image, color and transfer is crisp, clean, smooth and polished with pixellation visible at 40X magnification.  Beautiful.  Audio commentaries on plenty of episodes even though I haven't listend to them all yet.    CONS: The cover box art is disappointing; I'd expect that design from overseas collections.  There are no bonus features aside from obligatory and sparse production documentation, so bloopers, deleted scenes and the like are out.    WORST: Forget about skipping through episodes to get to your favorite parts: THERE ARE NO CHAPTER STOPS PAST THE SHOWS INTRODUCTION; skip ahead from chapter 3 and you'll end up at the credits.    *NOTE* Reports about a Disc 5 glitch have been listed: allegedly, some sets may contain a Disc 5 that has Episodes 1-4 RE-printed on it instead of 17-20.  My set is fine, but you might want to look into this report.    These things and the final one especially stripped the 5th star from my review.    Other than that, this is one of the better spin-offs and this is definitely one of the better Season 1's you'll find (thanks to franchise budgets).  The quality of the image, compactness of the box and tone of story make this set worth the buy.

B000B8QEZG|5.0|When I got wind that Madonna was finally releasing some new material, initial reports were that it was going to be her \\"Rock album\\" a la Franz Ferdinand and Killers.  So wasn't I surprised to hear later reports that not only was she not going Rock, but that her new release was actually going to be a straight-up Dance album! <br /> <br />I was a little nervous about the whole thing after the somewhat disappointing Music and the tepid reaction to American Life.  Although I loved that album, despite it's #1 debut, it was clear the rest of the world was not in agreement (despite, again, the fact it includes seven, yes seven, Top 10 dance singles). <br /> <br />Maybe this is why she decided to get back to her roots, as they say, and give the people what they want.  An album to pop on to dance around the room and forget the world exists. <br /> <br />I certainly had no need to be worried. <br /> <br />Madonna has returned to the dance floor, and she has come back with a vengeance. <br /> <br />The album kicks starts in overdrive with the blistering ABBA-sampled lead-off single, \\"Hung Up,\\" her best single in years, and doesn't let up for the first nine songs of the album!  The album includes two of the best songs she has ever recorded, \\"Sorry\\" (rumoured to be the second single and the best mainstream dance track she has recorded since \\"Vogue\\") and \\"Forbidden Love\\" (not to be confused with the song of the same name from her Bedtime Stories album).  It also includes a song which is a wink at her very own \\"Holiday,\\" as \\"Get Together\\" is seemingly loosely based on the groove that threw Madonna onto the edge of superstardom twenty-two years ago. <br /> <br />Honestly, there are nine seriously strong tracks on this album of twelve.  Each one has it's own feel, it's own vibe, but each one with a killer beat. <br /> <br />I feel she lost her footing a little by putting the \\"spiritual\\" track \\"Isaac\\" on here.  It seems very ill-placed on the album and is definitely, by far, the weakest track on the album, but not nearly as big a blemish as \\"I'm So Stupid\\" was to American Life.  \\"Let it Will be\\" and \\"Like it or Not\\" (produced by Bloodshy & Avant, best known for producing Britney Spears' worst single, \\"Toxic\\"), although two sufficiently good songs, are forgettable in the long run in comparison to the other nine slammin' tracks.  The fact that nine of twelve are strong, however, is far more than most albums can say these days. <br /> <br />The album is made up of high-BPM, high-concept dance tracks, slowing only ever-so-slightly near the end for the RnB-tinged \\"Push\\" which will hopefully get a release or a remix somewhere down the road. <br /> <br />The album showcases some of the best production she has ever done and some very clever lyrics.  Stuart Price, musical director of her Re-Invention Tour, but best known for producing and remixing this years dance sensation Juliet, along with his numerous dance remixes of artists like No Doubt, Killers, FischerSpooner and his very own remix of Madonna's \\"Hollywood,\\" co-produced eleven of the tracks on this album with Madonna.  The man is absolutely brilliant and truly brought out the best material Madonna has recorded in ages. <br /> <br />The most notable downfall of this album is that it is continuous.  Each song mixes into each other, and that really is a downside for those, like me, who prefer to listen to albums on shuffle.  Here's hoping there is an eventual release with all the songs separated.  And take note that the limited edition, featuring one extra song entitled \\"Fighting Spirit,\\" will be in stores on December 13th, just in time for Christmas. <br /> <br />Believe me, just for that one song, I will be first in line. <br />
B00020HEG6|4.0|I generally think John Williams is a little overrated--great, no doubt, but overrated.  There are simply way too many great composers out there for one to get the spotlight this often.  In addition, I think that his inspiration has been running dry as of late--other than his Star Wars, Iniana Jones (pretty much all of his '80s work in addition) and Schindler's list scores--he's been getting a little flat as of late.  Not anymore.  Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban is a great score. <br /> <br />Williams pretty much does away with Hedwig's theme most of the time, instead putting more emphasis on his new themes.  Those are: <br /> <br />A Window to the Past - This is one of the best themes Williams has ever composed.  Its representation on the album is a little short for someone like me who simply isn't satisfied with concert themes but rather integration of the theme into the rest of the score.  However, its power is undeniable. <br /> <br />Double Trouble - Not particularly great, but very effective in its contexts.  <br /> <br />Buckbeak's Theme - Another golden theme for a particular character scene from Williams. <br /> <br />The major problem with this soundrack is its arrangement on album--Williams sometimes has a problem with this.  In his best scores, he has concert arrangements of the major themes on album with the addition of lots of thematic development within the score.  Not so here.  \\"Double Trouble\\" is the only theme notably represented outside of its concert arrangement and \\"Finale,\\" and it works, but there's simply not enough coherence in the second half of the score.  Still, this stands as a wonderful achievement.

B000BGH22W|5.0|Unlike many, when I first heard that John Williams was replaced for Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, I didn't mind in the least.  The truth is that John Williams isn't as great as people make him out to be.  Don't get me wrong, he definitely is a great composer, but he gets the spotlight way too much, and other composers who are as good (if not better) but simply different get shoved to the side.  I enjoyed Williams' Potter scores, even if I didn't think they were as magical and coherent as they could have been (with the first two films I blame that on the director, and with the third I blame it on the album arrangement), but I still thought they were very good.  So I was very open-minded to hear what Patrick Doyle would bring us, having heard little of him but having loved what I heard.   <br /> <br />At first, this soundtrack struck me as a little flat.  After the second listen I decided that I had been temporarily deaf--this strikes gold in a way that Williams had never done.  Given, in a way, he was never given a chance to do this--Columbus was too cheesy, Cauron too subtle (but still brilliant) to really  work with this kind of material--but the fact remains that Doyle has crafted the first truly incredible large-budget accomplishment of his career. <br /> <br />The soundtrack, unlike the other three, moves chronologically through the film, and skips the attempt at concert suites.  For this reason, some may not pick up on the themes upon first listen.  I haven't seen the film so I can't say for sure, but I'll briefly outline what I believe to be the two major themes of this score: <br /> <br />Harry's Theme - Begins with a nice majestic treatment in \\"Foreign Visitors Arrive,\\" then moves through various modes:  a tender flute in \\"Harry Sees Dragons,\\" a bold, heroic statement at the end of \\"Golden Egg\\" and \\"The Black Lake,\\" and evolved into a tender love theme in \\"Harry In Winter.\\"   <br /> <br />Voldemort's Theme - Simple, but effective.  Its basically a sixnote ascending theme.  Its heard too many times to count, so I won't even try. <br /> <br />There are many other gorgeous themes, motifs, and rhythms in this score that makes it a very rich and complete listening experience.  The only detriment of the album is having the songs at the end.  I certainly think they will be appropriate for the Ball, but putting them at the end of the album kills the somber mood at the end, and in addition the lyrics are way too cheesy.  I'm not particularly fond of the style, either. <br /> <br />In the end, Doyle's score reigns supreme.  Here's to hoping he'll be kept for Order of the Phoenix in 2007.
B000002UB3|5.0|This is THE BEST rock album of all time. It never falls short to please the entire way through.  To quote one of my peers on here, this album seems like it had to come \\"from another planet\\".  It is so tight melodically that you can hardly believe your ears.  From the first bass lines of \\"Come Together\\" to McCartney's yearning, soulfull \\"Oh, Darling\\" to Harrisons \\"Something\\", and finally to the very fitting \\"The End\\" the album becomes something more than just music...it becomes an experience that everyone should know of, with a message found in every religion.  \\"And in the end, The love you take is equal to the love you make\\".  What you put into the world is what you will get out of it.  The Beatles gave something wonderful to the world here.  It is almost a sin to not have heard something so beautiful.

1591396190|4.0|Kim and Mauborgne present a compare and contrast analysis of Red Oceans (where most companies engage in bloody competition in a wide range of industries) vs Blue Ocean (where companies operate in new, uncontested waters).  The authors' description of Red Oceans is spot on - as they describe many industries with little real differentiation and the resulting intense competition.  Blue Oceans, on the other hand, offer the enticing prospect of clear differentiation, competitive advantage, and higher profit margins.  Although the framework, model and tools presented are interesting, it is not clear that the companies cited as operating in blue oceans actually went through anything resembling the strategic tools presented in order to create their \\"blue ocean\\" opportunities.  It is more of a post-hoc review.  That gripe notwithstanding, the book is worth a read, especially by those involved in strategic planning, market development, and new product development.
B00097DXZS|2.0|I'm glad I read the reviews here before putting this disc into my computer.  I've dealt with copy protection schemes on VHS, DVD, and computer software, and I have yet to see one that doesn't cause major technical glitches, to say the least.  However, what I'm reading here is going way beyond that.  Hopefully the backlash on this will be strong enough so that Sony and the other manufacturers will back off on this sort of nonsense.  (For details, see other reviews.)<br /><br />I doubt if Carlos Santana or any of his musicians are responsible for this.  I'd wager that the decision was made after the album was delivered and that Santana personally has no control over it.<br /><br />As for the record... this is another attempt to recapture the magic of Santana's big comeback hit, \\"Supernatural\\", and like its predecessor, \\"Shaman\\", it falls short.  There are some interesting songs, but it lacks that Spanish feel that made the diverse offerings of \\"Supernatural\\" fit together.  It's smooth and mostly enjoyable music, but nothing special.<br /><br />It's worthwhile for an old fogey like me, who grew up on Santana's earliest records, to get some exposure to newer performers, even if I'm only getting a taste.  \\"Supernatural\\" got me listening to Everlast, and I'm now a big fan.<br /><br />Note: I have an old stand-alone CD copying deck and had no problems burning a copy of this disc.  Perhaps CD-ROMs are so widely used that this type of deck is no longer being manufactured, but in any case the copy protection scheme is clearly doing more harm than good.  Based on what I've read here, I wouldn't take the chance of installing this on your computer.  Fortunately the album is not that great, so you can pass it up without missing too much.

Now that music has been packaged all into one.<br /><br />The Eurythmics Ultimate Collection, is a single disc compilation consisting of all of their big 80's hits. B000BTJDGC|3.0|If nothing else it was nice to see a \\"possession\\" movie that wasn't just a clone of 'The Exorcist.' I didn't really expect very much from the film though, and was pleasantly surprised when I wound up liking it. <br /> <br />Playing devil's advocate though (pardon the pun, I couldn't help it), I think I understand why some people may be a little critical. For me, the movie seemed very schizophrenic; as if it was torn between wanting to be a horror movie or a courtroom drama. This seeming indecision on which direction to take the film is noticeable and it hurts. The change of pace between the legal scenes and the flashbacks is severe. <br /> <br />The acting, I felt, was average. Laura Linney and Tom Wilkinson were both very good; conversely, Campbell Scott was just awful as the lead prosecutor. So, call it a wash. <br /> <br />The story's interesting, even despite the issue I mentioned earlier with the pacing. The production value is good, I felt like all the effects were all pretty well done. There was no half-hearted CGI shots inserted anywhere (i.e. `End of Days'). <br /> <br />Overall, I'm not sure you NEEDED to see this in the theater; I felt it would translate just as well as a rental. You could have honestly done either with a clear conscience though. Although I certainly wouldn't say it's a \\"must-see\\" it's definitely worth your time.

B000BGH22W|2.0|OVerall, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire Soundtrack was an enormous disappointment. Sadly, I found it lacking in memorable themes, the magical whimsy of its predicessors, and utterly out of place. <br />   Patrick Doyle is not a bad composer, don't get me wrong. However, I don't think his area of expertise lay in this genre and it was a mistake of the producers and directors of this film to choose him in light of John William's Absence. (for those of you wondering, Mr. william's did not write this score due to poor scheduling on his part (he was too tied up with \\"memoires of a Geisha\\")) <br />   Now, to the music itself. <br />    OVerall, i found this listening experience very unmemorable. Doyle is suited for a more historical, classical film style. He is excellent at composing for a more reminiscent, neoclassical feel (heard in the beginning of \\"QUidditch WOrld Cup\\"), which Harry Potter most certainly isn't.  <br />   With the exception of \\"The Black Lake\\", I found most of his more intense pieces were composed mainly of blaring horns and rushing strings, repeating the same frenzied antics over and over again. <br />   For his slower pieces, such as \\"Potter waltz\\" or \\"Harry in Winter\\", I found them to be very simiple (not necessarily bad) and difficult to follow. By this, I mean simply that music is supposed to tell the story. Many of his slower pieces gave off a feel, but not a sense of accomplishment. These generally revolve around a simple pattern used by many composers consisting of a major first, fourth, and fifth, and minor thirds and sixths. String these together with some well placed traveling notes in between and ta-dah! We have \\"Harry in Winter\\" (for example). <br />   Unlike my previously listening experiences with Mr. Williams (very magical times to be sure), I felt unsatisfied and groping to remember even the simplest of themes. However, the music is still good and I will put it on every now and then. <br />   Finally, we come to it at last. Thefinal three songs. I am not a fan of Jarvis COcker. I hadn't heard of him before he did this music and pray desperately that I will not hear him again. \\"Magic Works\\" and \\"THis is the Night\\" sounded vaguly reminiscent of a post-Beetle style (a group I also dislike emmensly), but much, much worse. <br />   Then, if that isn't bad enough we come to \\"Do the Hippogriff\\". If you really want to know what a man having his entrails and fingernails removed with an old, rusted knife sounds like, listen to the first thirty seconds of this song and you'll know what I'm talking about. <br />     If you are looking for some decent backround music, I have to say that this is deffinitely better than some of the stuff we have out there today. Just ignore the abominations at the end. <br />

0679745653|3.0|The central theme that brings together the stories in the book Breakfast at Tiffany's is personal loss. In the story \\"Breakfast at Tiffany's,\\" Holly and her husband separate, which is the first personal loss in the book. In \\"A Diamond Guitar,\\" an old man loses a younger man that he loves. This theme is present in all the stories.<br /><br /> The way these stories are all based on a common theme makes in easier for the reader to connect the stories more like a novel rather than a collection of short stories. This theme also serves as an organizational structure for the book. Although all the stories are unique, they all focus on the same issue.<br /><br /> The aspect of this book that sets it apart is its excellent organization. The way the stories are put together and all relate to each other shows how it is organized very well. The order that the stories are in also portrays the good organization because as the book progresses, the stories develop each other to form a main concept that is complete at the end.<br /><br /> In conclusion, Capote's well written book Breakfast at Tiffany's has an exemplary connected theme throughout all the stories it contains. The book connects to everyone who picks it up by relating to personal loss in several circumstances. Without a doubt, Breakfast at Tiffany's is Truman Capote at his finest.

B000B63EZG|3.0|Sew up \\"Master of Puppets\\" with Iron Maiden and In Flames riffs and a predisposition towards gothic lyrical melodrama and artistic expression a la The Cure (\\"Tears Don't Fall,\\" \\"Hand of Blood,\\" \\"Suffocating Under Words of Sorrow (What Can I Do),\\" etc.). Then, add some kids with a tour van full of black hair dye and replacement belt studs, and you have this band.<br /><br />Like other albums made by bands pillaging the legacy of Gothenburg, \\"The Poison\\" is chock full of harmonized lead guitar set against a pounding rhythm section, and the vocals swerve between the extremes of an on-the-verge-of-suicide Billie Joe Armstrong and Varg Vikernes with a sore throat. It's too hard to be pop, but it's too whiny to be metal; it's too derivative to be praised as a classic, but Bullet for My Valentine are too Welsh to be overlooked by record companies in the wake of other successful acts from Wales like Funeral for a Friend and Lostprophets.<br /><br />Like the records that inspired it, \\"The Poison\\" gets old quick, but moments of unadulterated six string masturbation sprinkled throughout will bring you out of the inevitable tunnel vision reverie Bullet for My Valentine's songwriting will induce.<br /><br />Bottom line: if you're itching for a new Atreyu record, here it is. Otherwise, skip it.

B000BGH22W|3.0|First off, I want to conduct an experiment - I'm writing a detailed review - albiet a negative one about this score, though I am sure it will garner tons of \\"unhelpful\\" points because fans will use it simply as a popularity contest(well, we'll see).  I have been somewhat indifferent to John Williams' previous Harry Potter scores.  Granted, they have been memorable, and his themes were great, but somehow I felt there was so much more potential and that Williams' score was too \\"ordinary\\".  When I heard Patrick Doyle was now doing HP4's score, I didn't know whether to be interested or not.  I haven't heard too much about him doing this kind of work, so I decided to just wait and hear it before making any prejudgements.  And so, here we are.    Doyle's score is not memorable.  That's not to say it is bad.  Only that it doesn't quite give you anything to stick in your mind after a listen.  Perhaps it fulfills the job of sticking with the image on screen and presenting underscore to fulfill it's duty, but other composers have shown us music can add to the film rather than just support it.  Doyle doesn't not do this.  John Williams sometimes did this too, but at least he presented some good themes mixed into the mush.  Doyle does provide themes, but they are not too memorable.  I don't know how well it works in the film, but it just sounds too \\"heard it all before\\".  There isn't much original concepts.  And again, reused concepts can sound good when done well (like John Williams), but Goblet of Fire just ends up sounding like one big mush of unmememorable music.    The CD opens with \\"The Story Continues\\" which presents some expected kind of music with Hedwig's theme popping up but not doing much other than being present.  There isn't too much of Williams' previous themes being used throughout the album.  \\"The Quidditch World Cup\\" is something of a joke.  We swiftly move through some uninteresting tracks of average underscore, the kind that you watch in the movie and don'treally remember later, and find \\"Rita Skeeter\\", a track which certainly does not live up to the potential of it's subject.  Some unexciting string play is what Doyle uses to represent this character.    We continue with the uninspiring underscore in \\"Sirius Fire\\" until we reach \\"Harry Sees Dragons\\", an average track which manages to hold interest while again, not presenting much in originality.  \\"Golden Egg\\" starts with some bombastic material and continues into the cliched action scoring.      \\"Neville's Waltz\\" is of course appropriately title as a waltz.  It is really the first interesting track in the album, and leads to the next track \\"Harry in Winter\\", which opens with a theme that sounds like it's for another movie.  Nevertheless, I can say it is the first track I enjoyed listening to thusfar, and I hoped it would bring about more good parts to come.  His approach to the track isn't that new, high strings playing the sweet melody with a lower support.      The big higlight, is, of course, \\"Voldemort\\", as it represents the big villain and climatic higlight.  The approach isn't too original, scary chords with brass and rumbling percussion.  \\"Death of Cedric\\" was really the moment I was looking forward to in this movie, as it is a fantastic emotional moment in the book, but I was severely disappointed with what Doyle provides.  It is just way too dull and formulaic with it's \\"sadly\\" vibrating high strings and doesn't get emotional at all, leaving you wishing for something that did.  The score kicks off with \\"Another Year Ends\\", which I suppose is a satisfactory \\"The End\\" piece with it's balance between happy and sad.    I may have seemed a bit harsh during my review of the individual tracks, but I will say, as a whole, the track isn't bad.  It's just that there are zero memorable moments present.  It is a decent film score to support the film, but it never amounts to anything more than that.  It sounds too much like \\"auto-compose\\" and I never hear anything original or anything which really gets your attention.  It is an average film score and not more or less.  Is it better that Williams' previous scores?  No, I don't think it is, but it is a decent score in it's own right to support the film.  However, I don't think I will relisten to it any time soon.
0804106304|3.0|The Joy Luck Club, I cannot help but admit, is a good book. It is a book that is precisely what daughters and mothers should read as I believe it reveals a lot of the infrastructure of these relationships, and has the capability to make such people aware of their own relationships. Not that I'm saying this book is a tell-all self-help book, revealing the Top Ten Secrets to Successfully Getting Along With Your Daughter, or the Top Five Real Ways that Daughters Piss off Their Mothers. It is, of course, fiction. It is a book of interlacing short stories about Chinese mothers and their American/Chinese daughters. It is a story of the clash between mothers and their daughters, both literally and metaphorically through the addition of the cultural differences that seem to separate them. Each daughter has her own trial that she must overcome, and, in some way, it is reflective (or refractive) of her own mother's trials that she struggled with while still in China. Amy Tan beautifully demonstrates that the relationship of the mother and daughter is so closely related that it moves beyond blood and into circumstance, and that not even culture or language can separate them. <br />The only problem with this book comes from the fact that I am a guy. I have no doubt that I am a guy, and therefore am quite secure in saying that this book is not for guys. A guy may read it, may be entertained by it, but it won't hold the same impact, the same punch that it delivers to the women who read this book. Only vicariously can I feel the emotion that Tan is putting into this book, and that only through seeing someone else, female, reading the book and talking about how close to home it hit them and how close to tears they got. Otherwise, all I see is a bunch of women having their problems, arguing about them, and coming to some sort of conclusion by the end. Though, I say this while at the same time complementing Tan's prose, and being amazed at her ability to put words and cultures together to create such a beautiful volume of stories. I don't know, maybe it's just the fact that almost every guy in this story seems to be described as being ignorant, dumb, or, in some form, a dirty rotten jerk. I've heard bad things about my sex (being gender, just so you know), but I'm not convinced that we're all bad (or that these women aren't, in some way, just as bad... but I will duck away before I make anyone mad and cease my meandering comments).  <br />

B000B8QEZG|5.0|When fans and pop radio stations lost interest in American Life (which was a decent album, saved by Die Another Day, Nobody Knows Me, Hollywood, and Nothing Fails), Madonna knew she had her work cut out for her.  She decided to put her preachy, Kabbalist perspective on hold in favor for fluffy dance music.  The stretch from Hung Up through How High is breathtaking.  Highlights include the most commercial track Hung Up, followed by my personal favorite Get Together with its Daft-Punk inspired soundscape.  It's reminiscient of the remixed rendition of Holiday from her smash Re-Invention Tour.  It's followed by the rumored 2nd single Sorry.  The chorus is beyond catchy.  Mirwais pops up with Future Lovers, a brilliant filler, for an album heavy on potential hits.  As silly as the lyrics to I LOVE NY, Madonna's confrontational, in your face persona reappears and boi do we wish we saw more of it throughout the album.  It's followed by another great filler, LEt it Will be, perhaps sampling Die Another Day?  NO complaints here.  Forbidden Love is another favorite of mine.  This is the closest moment we get to touch a ballad.  Perhaps my favorite filler of the bunch.  Another potential single is JUMP, reminding us of how capable Madonna is in creating a simple, catchy pop tune.  The buzz ends after How High, a highly entertaining, however preachy, song.  The final quarter of the album, containing ISAAC, PUSH, and LIKE IT OR NOT is rather disappointing, primarily due to Madonna's incessant belief in conveying 'deep' messages to the masses.  However, there are 5 potential global smash singles, and between them are excellent fillers.  Perhaps one of Madonna's greatest albums and a must buy.  Album of 2005!
B000BO0LLS|1.0|Mariah Carey, the comeback queen of 2005, shocked the industry with her deservedly successful album \\"The Emancipation of Mimi.\\"  (See my 4-star review for my thoughts on the music)  It achieved what was considered unthinkable just three years ago: multiplatinum sales and a string of hits for the once-troubled diva.  Apparently, that's not good enough for Universal, the parent company of Mariah's label.  This week, they've released two additional editions of \\"Mimi,\\" and, frankly, neither of them is worth your time and money.  The \\"Ultra Platinum Edition\\" has four bonus tracks and a DVD featuring the music videos \\"It's Like That,\\" \\"We Belong Together,\\" \\"Shake it Off,\\" and \\"Get Your Number.\\"  Before I get to the bonus material, I can't help but wonder why Universal felt the need to release a total of FOUR versions of the same album within one year.  It's part of an unsettling trend in the music industry (forcing fans to pay for the same music at least twice), and it proves just how desperate these labels are for sales.  The additional bonus songs include the single \\"Don't Forget About Us\\" and a remix of her Number One hit \\"We Belong Together.\\"  They're not bad, but why couldn't these tracks be released separately on an EP?  Adding a mere four songs onto previously released material is frankly insulting.  As I mentioned before in another review, I have nothing against labels that reissue classic records.  But re-releasing a multiplatinum album within months of its release is tacky and it's an all-too-transparent way to milk a cash cow dry.  If you have no version of \\"Mimi,\\" and you really love Mariah, then this edition is the way to go.  But if you already have the original release and you feel the urge to grab this one, then you should follow the advice of one of Mariah's titles: shake it off.

If you've read the book, it follows it more closely than the original. And most of all, if you like chocolate as much as I do, your mouth will be watering.  <br /> <br />Just as the you would expect, the movie is full of vibrant colors, wonderful effects, and surprises around every corner. The story of Willy Wonka and how he came to be is a welcome addition to the story, and Johnny Depp's portrayal of the estranged maker of sweet treats is outstanding. The Oompa Loompas in this version are very different from the original, and the guy who plays them is a riot. The performances by all the other actors are also terrific. There's no point in going into any detail about the story line of this movie other than you just need to see it for yourself. <br /> <br />Both movies are very different from each other, and you have to view this version knowing that. If you're expecting to see Johnny Depp make an attempt at copying Gene Wilder, then you're not giving him enough credit. As I mentioned before, this is not a remake of the original movie... this is simply Tim Burton's way of transforming the book into movie form, and presenting it in his own unique style. <br /> <br />Anyone who gives this movie a negative review simply doesn't get it. Their minds are closed, their imaginations lost, and they do not see this movie for all it's worth.

Both CDs showed incredible talent (in my humble opinion), Motherland especially.  <br /> <br />I have to say though that Ophelia has moved me beyond compare. Ms. Merchant's voice, the enunciation of each syllable to its completion, the sense that she might be smiling during a certain word as it is being sung, singing the lyrics with such emotion from soaring and commanding to nearly a whisper---it's hard to describe, but just her vocal skills alone completely overwhelmed me, as if I were in a small room sitting next to her. Yes, some of the lyrics might sound depressing, but who on this earth hasn't ever struggled with difficult issues in their life and hoped for comfort or understanding? This CD gives both and more. Buy it and play it on a quiet night, when you can listen to it in its entirety with no interruptions. Depending who you are or what you like, you may keep listening to it many more times to come. I would give it 10 stars if I could and nominate it for Natalie Merchant's best offering so far.

1400031087|1.0|Since there are over 700 reviews already posted for this book, I'd normally hesitate to add another, but maybe I can save someone else from being scammed by Mr. Frey. First, the writing is, as others have pointed out, repetitive, ungrammatical, self-indulgent, and repetitive (read one page of the book and you'll understand). Second, while many other reviewers have hailed this book's brutal honesty, they are only half-correct in their assessment. Brutal it certainly is, both in the things Frey describes and the method he uses to describe them, bludgeoning the reader into submission. Honest, however, I doubt that it is. Not only do I have a hard time believing some of the things he claims happened in a respected, world-famous re-hab facility, much of the characters, scenes and dialog are reminiscient of a bad movie. I suspect that ninety percent of this \\"memoir\\" is fiction. For instance, I Googled for stories of a former featherweight champion being shot outside of a crack-house (or just being murdered anywhere) and I came up empty. Gee, you think something like that would have made the papers.   <br /> <br />I have no doubt that Mr. Frey's journey through addiction, re-hab, and recovery was harrowing. I also have no doubt that, in that journey, there is a story worth telling. My guess is that he realized early on that he wasn't a good enough writer to make the story of that journey compelling, so he filled it with a tough-guy pose and host of made-for-TV dramatic clichs. In so doing, he crosses the line between poetic license and fiction. Of course, if this book had been marketed as fiction, no editor would have bought it. It's just bad, self-indulgent writing. <br /> <br />Oprah, your book club is great, but you need to have a higher standard than just the author's willingness to be on your show with his mom.

B0009XT8YW|5.0|I had not listened to my vinyl version of \\"Guilty\\" in its entirety in a long time, but after hearing the 25th Anniversary CD version, I was reminded of something that I first realized way back in 1980 - this is just a brilliant pop record. It has great songwriting, great production, and amazing vocal performances. Writing for Streisand brought out some of Barry Gibb's best songs, and singing these songs created some of Streisand's best vocal performances. Streisand is never less than amazing to listen to, but there is just something extra in her singing on \\"Guilty\\" that reaches a new level. I think that something extra is that she was having FUN singing these songs. The new interviews on the Dual Disc version seem to confirm this. Working with Barry Gibb at the height of his creativity was one of the best decisions that Barbra ever made and the result was this glorious example of pop brilliance.
055380457X|5.0|\\"The Google Story\\" is a book with a very wide appeal. Written by a journalist (David Vise), it is pretty much structured as a tale that can be enjoyed as much by the technically inclined as it can be loved by the ones focused on the business side of things. As much as you could argue that it's rather one-sided, I have yet to meet people who hate Google, in the way many people hate Microsoft. I am no one to say there's nothing to dislike about them (as a matter of fact, the book gives you plenty to read about this matter), but part of the point the book intends to get across is that they are very particular in terms of the way they positioned themselves from day one (notice I didn't say unique).<br /><br />Under the mantra \\"Don't Be Evil\\", the story of Google is one that is intimately tied to the personalities and life visions of founders, Sergey Brin and Larry Page. And as much as their success and meteoric rise of their stock may bother some, when you read the book you understand why they have gotten so far. Quite simply, it shows how they layed one brick upon another, focusing on developing an extraordinary product that addressed real needs of users, rather than burning expensive advertising dollars to create a buzz around empty promises (quite the norm at the time of the Internet boom, during which they started their company).<br /><br />A must for entrepreneurs at heart. One tale after another that geeks will enjoy. I give it five stars without a doubt. You will find yourself devouring it in no time, after you pick it up.
B000BT97AO|5.0|I had the very good fortune to see this little gem on the big screen. It's a lot to absorb! This is a movie clearly written for grown-ups who still retain their ability to sit still and let go with their imagination. It's a true work of art, and as a result, was not commercially viable in the United States. It barely made it into the theaters! What a shame!<br /><br />What is wrong with the vast majority of American movie goers? Here in the States we fawn over and spend huge amounts of money on formula-film-trash. But when a film with heart, mind-boggling originality, real imagination, great storyline, stimulating soundtrack, decent acting, wonderful cinematography, and amazing special effects by some of the greatest animators in the entire world, it barely makes a blip on the radar screen. Was this the fault of rather timid distribution? I'm sure it didn't help matters! But ultimately, it's the American desire for violence and perpetual petulant titillation that runs many a decent movie into the proverbial financial ground!<br /><br />I'm truly looking forward to purchasing this gem when it becomes available on DVD! One of the very few movies I have seen this year, which I would like to see a second time. While most of 2005 has been a year of terrible flops, and way too many disappointments, Mirrormask gives me hope for a brighter movie going future! Thank you all for sticking your collective necks out by making this surprisingly good film! It will certainly stand the test of time!
B000002UA2|4.0|Pink Floyd seem to be a band to hit the nail in the head every time they set out to do music for a movie. They can even record an album (supposedly) timed to a movie (\\"Dark Side...\\") even if it wasn't the original music FOR the movie. \\"Obscured By Clouds\\" is the second album they recorded for a Barbet Schroeder movie (\\"More\\" being the first one), and the third soundtrack they'd put together. With the title track as one of Pink Floyd's darkest opening songs, the album navigates eventually into mellower territory, landing in \\"Wots... Uh the Deal\\", one of the most beautiful ballads they ever recorded, and yet another ballad (\\"Stay\\") which I cannot help enjoying too. Ironic how an essentially dark album, which opens and ends with eery instrumental tracks, can yield some of the band's softer works in years. If you are putting together your PF collection, there may better albums to get first, but this one will not stay away from it for too long.

Corey's vocals aren't as dark as they are on the album but still great. 10/5<br /><br />4. Before I Forget: An emotional track. Left Behind: Lead single off the Iowa album, I would have rather seen \\"My Plague\\" rather than this but still a great song. 4.5/5<br /><br />6. Liberate: as soon as Mick starts that single riff, you can FEEL the excitement in the crowd, the song does not dissapoint, live version is better than the studio one actually. 5/5<br /><br />7. Pulse of the Maggots: When I first heard this song a few months prior to the release of Vol. 3 I always thought this would be a song that they would rip up live (in a positive way) they don't let down.
